conversations.content: Rrrrrraaaaaaagh! Thaaat's it! I'm done! I AIN'T DOIN' NO MORE!
Enough with the cleaning! I wanna have some FUN!
A boy may have fun  when his chores are all done.
Aw, I hate rhymes that tell me bad news... C'moooon, Cleo! I mean, yeah, I get it, dirt is the enemy or whatever, but it's NEW YEAR'S!
Most people spend the end of the year celebrating, but WE go nuts cleaning this joint from attic to cellar. What gives?!
Well, because... Er...
We're all partied out from Dragonyule, but instead of sleeping it off, I'm scrubbin' grout. The holidays are s'posed to be for relaxing, not THIS!
We clean precisely BECAUSE the year is ending.
Yeah, that's always how we roll over in Hinomoto.
Wait, really?
Of course. Who would not wish to begin the new year with a fresh slate as well as a clean home?
Besides, cleaning is thought to welcome both happiness and good fortune into your home for the coming year.
Welcoming good fortune, hm? That's an interesting way of thinking about it.
You didn't know, Cleo? I thought that's why you were joining in on the tradition.
No, I'd never heard of it. I just feel like the Halidom deserves some respect and thanks after serving us for the year.
An equally beautiful sentiment.
The New Year's decorations we put out after cleaning also mean stuff.
Our culture's pretty deep when you get right down to it!
Okay, now I'm curious. Tell me more!
It is ever a joy to share our ways with friends from abroad. But first...
We clean.
*sigh* Yes, ma'am.
You know, I think this every year, but between the decorations and the kimonos, you guys really go all out!
Oh, speaking of, you said the decorations had some kind of special meaning, yeah?
Well, what's with the stack of mochi wearing a fruit hat?
Those are known as kagami mochi. It is a most auspicious food that symbolizes a wish for a bountiful harvest as we embark on the new year.
There is also meaning in the fact that the mochi are stacked upon each other.
There are also prescriptions for where they are to be displayed, as well as what day one should put them out.
All that just for rice cakes?
Oh, yes. We have rituals for all of our decorations, including the kadomatsu bamboo ornaments and shimenawa ropes.
Wow, man. We're pretty close allies with you guys and I had NO idea...
I would be happy to teach you more if you desire; part of my role here IS as a cultural emissary, after all.
In that case, lay it on me! This stuff is all super rad, PLUS I get to learn more about all of you guys!
I am glad to hear it. In that case, let me begin with the decorations...
After hearing all about Hinomotoan New Year's ornamentation, Luca excitedly ran off...
Where do you suppose he went?
Gah?! What's happening?!
Yo, Ranzal! He went that way!
On it!
Is everyone here all right?! I heard a most terrifying racket.
Yeah, funny story! After you taught me all about those ornaments, I got the urge to do a little decorating myself.
I was walking through the forest, saw a big ol' fiend, and thought, ＂Hey! I bet THAT guy could use a little holiday festivity!＂
Gnrgh?!
And this chaos is the result.
Put. It. Back. NOOOOW!
Whew! He's a slippery fella, but I finally wrangled him into that cage.
Thanks, man. I'll take it from here.
I can safely say it has never occurred to me to decorate a fiend. As I THOUGHT I explained earlier, these ornaments are—
Oh, yeah! About that! I'd love to hear more about all your guys' celebrations.
I mean, yeah, okay. Probably shouldn't have tried to hang stuff on a fiend's teeth. But next time will be WAY better.
Plus, Hinomoto's our buddy! I wanna get to know you all better.
That is...a fine sentiment.
Look, more than anything, I wanna have FUN this New Year's, so lay it on me! Gimme Hinomotoan New Year's 101!
Very well. I'll shall spread the word.
Let's all have a lovely year-end together.
Woooo! This year, we're doin' it up full-on Hinomoto style!
Thank you...for all the kindness you showed me...this...year! Done!
A very...Happy New Year to you... with best wishes for...the year to come.
Hey, what are you guys up to? Writing postcards?
They're not just any postcards. These are called nengajo.
Okay, I'll bite. The heck's a nengajo?
You don't know?!
Nope. This another Hinomotoan New Year's tradition?
Yep! We send 'em out early so they arrive right at the start of the new year.
You write people you're close to in order to thank them for the last year and wish them well in the new one.
Well, ain't that wild? We send Dragonyule cards here in Alberia—sounds like that's more or less the same thing.
Pretty much, yeah. It's really fun thinking of what to write to everyone on your list.
It also offers a fine opportunity to reflect on relationships at the close of the year.
Niiice. You guys mind if I give it a go?
Sure! I'm happy to walk you through it.
Heck yeah! Gimme some cards!
My buddies better watch out, 'cause I'm slinging some spicy nengajo their way!
A few days later...
You're getting good with that brush, Luca!
Thanks...
Are you feeling all right? You look...pale.
Yeah, sure. Fine. I'll sleep as soon as I finish the last one of these.
You haven't slept? But you've been writing those for DAYS!
Yeah, but every time I think about who needs one, the list keeps growing...
And THEN I have to come up with a personalized message for each of them, and this ink and brush thing is NOT easy.
Trust me, it's been a spilled-ink tsunami around this place lately.
But if I don't put my heart and soul into 'em, what's the point?
Your dedication to your friends is really quite remarkable.
And when you have so many, it can be quite the undertaking. Well, just lemme know if I can help out, okay?
Now that I've heard your reasons, I won't try to stop you!
Heh. Thanks.
No, thank YOU! I'm touched to see you so eager to share in our Hinomotoan culture.
Huh? Why wouldn't I be?
...Little wonder you have such a long list.
Now, what can I do?
Man, if you could prep some ink for me, that'd be a real solid. Oh, and maybe a spare brush?
By your command!
They're in your hands now, Francesca.
Leave it to me! I'll see them delivered at once through my network.
Gotta say, though, I don't think I've ever seen a stack of postcards this big. You just get back from a trip around the world?
Those are called nengajo—Hinomotoans send 'em as a kind of combo New Year's greeting and a thank-you for the previous year.
Well, aren't you quite the expert!
Heh. Yeah, I had good teachers. Oh, here—this one's yours.
For me?
＂Thanks for keeping the supplies flowing year-round. Let's make this a good one.＂
Urk... Little awkward hearing that read out loud right in front of me.
And a little awkward to read it! I'm not used to being thanked for doing my job.
Guess we don't often take the time to say that kinda stuff even to friends.
And we don't often get to hear it! ...This is really sweet, Luca. Thank you.
I'll make sure these get delivered so everyone has a chance to feel like this.
See you later!
Take care out there!
...Whew!
Luca!
Can I please just go to bed?
Of course! For as long as you like!
He must be exhausted.
Ha ha! Yeah, but it's a good reminder of why he has so many friends.
I feel fortunate to be one of them.
Though if his to-do list of nengajo grows with each new friend he makes...
His New Year's are only going to get more and more brutal as the years go on!
Eh, I'm sure he'll power through.
Without a doubt.
Zzz...
Heh. Sleep well, Luca. You earned it.
Happy New Year, one and all!
Happy New Year. I'm glad we made it through another one safe and sound.
Wooo! Okay, so what's the first thing we do to ring in the new year Hinomoto-style?
Er, why are you asking me?
Because you were standing there? Relax, it ain't a trick question.
Urk. Okay...
Traditionally, we would start with the first shrine visit of the new year.
First what now?
On the first day of the new year, we go to a shrine to offer our prayers.
We give thanks for living through the last year and to ask for happiness in the next.
And you do this at a shrine, yeah? What's that all about?
Well, many of our shrines are dedicated to the goddess Amaterasu. There are even statues of her contained within.
I understand those of the Ilian Church pray to a statue of their goddess, while sylvans pray to the forest itself.
Similarly, we offer prayers at shrines— in this case, for a safe and happy year.
Gotcha. Okay, let's do it!
I'm sorry?
The first visit thing! Let's go.
I'm not aware of any Hinomotoan shrines existing in Alberia.
Well yeah, but the point is to thank and pray to the thing watchin' over us, right?
Cause we've DEFINITELY got one of those!
Oh?
Ohhh. Yes, that's quite the sight.
If there's one thing we can be thankful for saving our butts on the daily, it's dragons!
No arguments there.
So how do we do this thing, huh? Go prostrate? Pound the chest? Is there wailing involved? I love wailing!
Er, do what?
The first shrine visit thing! Focus, man! There's gotta be a protocol, yeah?
Oh, er, yes. Of course. Well, to start with, we bow once before the torii.
Before what?
Put simply, it's the gate to the shrine. So in this case, I suppose it would be the garden entrance?
There!
Okay, that's done. Next?
We wash our hands and mouth at the water station.
Huh? But I'm already all clean and shiny.
Perhaps that's the case physically, but... Look, that's just how it works.
Why?
Because I said so. Now, here's how you wash: Take the dipper in your right hand, scoop the water, and then proceed.
Okay, I see. So it's sorta like a cleansing of the body, yeah?
Just so. Though as we have no water station here, we can skip that step and—
No skipping!
I'm gonna go clean up, and I mean the works—EEEVERY last nook and cranny!
What?! Oh dear. I don't understand ANY of this, and all the chaos is starting to make my stomach hurt...
Okay! Back and freshly bathed! Seriously, I'm sparkling. *gleam*
That is...fine, I suppose? Now we ring the shrine bell and pray—though we probably don't have such a thing around here.
Howzabout the one around Mariti's neck? I bet it rings like a champ.
The children of the choir gave me this. It's my most precious treasure.
Aww, c'mon, lemme ring it! I promise to pray some extra gratitude your waaay...
Oh, very well. If you must. But only this once!
Right, that takes care of the bell. Oh, but before you ring it, you have to place an offering in the coin box.
But as we have no coin box, we can sk—
NO SKIPPING! C'mon, I wanna do this right—or as close as possible, anyway.
May I ask why the most laid-back person in the entire Halidom is suddenly such a stickler for exacting protocol?
Because it's my friends' culture and I don't want to do a half-butt job of it! It's a respect thing, yeah?
I ain't gonna disrespect Hinomoto OR you!
I see now that it is more than good cheer which brings people to your side.
Huh?
You're happy-go-lucky, but still sincere. It's the combination of the two that earns you their trust—and mine.
Easy, now! You're gonna give me an ego. Seriously though, thanks for that. Anyway, what's next? And don't ski—
Worry not; I'll be sure to give you the full and unabridged version.
You better!
You had quite the intense look while you held your hands together. Might I ask what you were praying for?
I asked for a ton of new friends.
The more, the merrier!
Heh. I doubt you need to worry about that.
Huh? Why's that?
You truly need to ask?
(He has no self-awareness about his cheerfulness OR sincerity. He's just... himself. Totally, wonderfully artless.)
(His true heart will resonate with others', and they will willingly open up to him. I now see that first-hand.)
I hope this year will be a good one, Luca.
You say that like it's up to chance! We're gonna make it great together!
Ha ha, right you are, my friend. I have full faith we'll see that prediction fulfilled.
Phew! Made it.
Man, this place hasn't changed at all.
LUCAAAA!
Heeey! You been good while I was out?
Whoa! What are you wearing?!
It's called a kimono—they wear 'em in a far-off place called Hinomoto. Pretty sharp, huh?
You mean...they don't show their belly button in Hinomoto?
Nope! I feel bad depriving the world of it, but these are the sacrifices we make!
Ah, Luca. You're back.
Just got in, actually.
It's unusual to get a visit from you out of the blue. To what do we owe the pleasure?
It's New Year's!
And? I mean, yeah, it's a holiday, but it's not THAT big a deal.
Though I guess humans tend to make more of a fuss about it in some nations.
Sylvans give a quick prayer to the woods, float some offerings down the river, eat a meal, and boom! We're done.
Did you really make the trip just for that?
Course I did—so let's get started!
You having fun, Luca? Got any good stories from the outside world?
Oh, you bet! Plus, there's something I wanna do with everybody here.
Oh?
Yeah! It's this thing where we all go around thanking each other.
Sounds nice and all, but...why?
Some of my buddies are from this country out east called Hinomoto, and they've been teaching me how they do New Year's there.
Those guys are ALL ABOUT giving thanks. They go nuts for it.
They send postcards, do shrine visits... Tons of stuff to try and say thanks for last year and wish for good times to come.
And you want to convert us all to this Hinomoto way?
Nah, nothing like that; I dig the way we do New Year's, too.
This ain't a competition, and I'm not trying to say whose culture does it best.
It's just opened my eyes to just how important expressing gratitude is. So I was thinking we could use a bit of that warm-fuzzy feeling here, too!
It's not about race or where you're from, or about specific cultures or traditions. It's just about...us, you know? Everybody.
Guess I can't argue with that.
It's so easy to forget to put your feelings into words and just assume others know how important they are to you.
Yeah, we all take it for granted, which is why I want a better way.
Most of the time, I'm far away from the village, so I don't get many opportunities to tell you guys how I feel.
But seeing how Hinomotoans do it made me realize I HAD the opportunity— I just wasn't making it happen.
So I came back home to spend New Year's with you guys.
Anyway, thanks for everything this year. Let's make the next one even better!
Hey, don't mention it! We're all one big family, after all! Thanks, Luca. I'm glad we all get to put up with each other for another year.
And I love how you always tell us stories from the outside!
I ALSO love how my mom always makes super yummy food! Thanks, Mom!
It's my pleasure, sweetheart. Thank YOU for always cleaning your plate.
Whoa...
Ha ha! Not bad, Luca!
(Eh, I guess I can tell him—but ONLY because it's a special occasion.)
(He deserves to know how much I respect the way he cares for the people in his life. Not only that, but he always tries to help everyone become their best self.)
(Not to mention how much he's taught me...)
Yo, Sarisse! Get over here!
I'm coming, ya dope!
(Hope you're ready, Luca, 'cause this won't be no ordinary Sarisse thank-you!)
I ate so much... I partied sooo muuuch...
It was all too good to pass up... I think I'm gonna burst...
Too much...food... Bury me...with my leftovers...
We played hanetsuki, we flew kites, we spun tops around...
Hinomoto's New Year's goes hard, and it's all so damn much fun! But I want a rematch on those tops.
How many rounds does this make?!
It seems you've enjoyed a Hinomotoan New Year to its fullest.
Absolutely! Thanks for teaching me so much about it, both of you.
Well then, sounds like it's time to draw things to a close.
Aw, can't we keep it going just a LITTLE longer?
If every day were New Year's, it wouldn't feel so special.
It's wonderful precisely because you only get one short taste of it each year.
I get all that, but it's still hard to switch out of party mode.
Then why don't we do the first calligraphy of the year to help get us motivated?
What's that about?
At the start of the year, we write down goals and ideals for the new year to help focus our resolves.
And as we use a brush to write them out, it's also an act of dedication to improving one's penmanship.
Hey, NOW you're talking! After writing all those nengajo out, I've gotten pretty good with the ol' brush!
Heh. You're gonna have to prove it!
Let's get our goals clear in our minds so they might guide us in the year to come.
This damn thing's impossible...
Excellent work, Luca!
I got a lot of practice in with nengajo— though this one's thicker than my old one.
...Hey, nice! I finished mine.
The character you've chosen is ＂friend.＂
Yep! It's 'cause of my friends that I got to have such an incredible New Year's.
Plus, you made me realize a few things. Even inspired me to go back and ring in the new year in my hometown.
All in all, this New Year's has taught me that the most important things in life are my good pals.
And whatever changes come, I know that'll be constant.
Anyway, I wrote this out in the hopes I never take it for granted.
Something unchanging throughout the years is quite beautiful indeed.
Heh. Thanks. And thanks again to all of you for helping me remember that.
I mean it, you guys.
You're all amazing.
Thank you, Luca...
Huh? What was that?!
And why is it giving me deja vu...?
Oh crap! I totally forgot!
I was supposed to take that fiend I decorated back to the forest!
Must've finally busted out of its cage. Whoopsie!
...WELL?! Go get it already!
TEAR IT LIMB FROM LIMB!
Look at Hanabusa's face!
I guess a fiend showing up finally pushed him over his limit...
Let's hope his new year's resolution is to learn a little more control. Anyhoo, we better help out before those two wreck the entire place.
Come, everyone! We've a fiend to capture!
Uh oh. Looks like I missed my cue.
It was all so lovely, but then...chaos.
I didn't even get the chance to hand out these gift envelopes.
With money inside, yes? That's another Hinomotoan New Year's tradition, I recall.
Yep. When I heard Luca was studying their culture so diligently, I thought he deserved a little reward.
Guess that'll have to wait.
Perhaps it is for the best. You'll likely need those funds to repair the castle.
Well, at least we know this new year won't be a boring one!
